skill: Student can recognize that equivalent fractions show the same amount of the same-sized whole
problem_type: Student selects which bar from 3 options shows an equivalent fraction to a reference bar
workspace_description: Reference FracShape bar at top showing target fraction with shading and label visible. Three FracShape option bars below with different partitions. One option is equivalent to reference, two are distractors. All bars are same total size.
prompt_examples: Which bar shows the same amount as one half?
Find the bar that is equivalent to two fourths.
Click the bar that shows an equivalent fraction.
One half is shaded at the top. Which bar below matches that amount?
Which bar is equivalent? Click to select.
action_description: Student clicks one of the three option bars to select it
correct_end_state: Student has selected the bar showing the fraction equivalent to the reference
success_dialogue: That's right. Two fourths shows the same amount as one half.
You found it. Three sixths equals one half.
Correct — same amount, different pieces.
Yes. Four eighths is equivalent to one half.

skill: Student can recognize that equivalent fractions show the same amount of the same-sized whole
problem_type: Student selects ALL pairs of fraction bars that show equivalent fractions from a set of 4-5 pairs
workspace_description: 2 rows displayed vertically (max 4 FracShapes due to toy limit). Each row contains two FracShape bars representing a comparison pair. One pair is equivalent, one is not. All bars are same total size.
prompt_examples: Select all the pairs that show equivalent fractions.
Click all the pairs where both bars show the same amount.
Find all the equivalent pairs. There may be more than one.
Which pairs are equivalent? Select all that apply.
Some pairs show the same amount. Find them all.
action_description: Student clicks to select multiple pairs, then confirms selection
correct_end_state: Student has selected exactly the pairs that show equivalent fractions
success_dialogue: You found them both. One half equals two fourths, and three sixths equals four eighths.
That's right — those pairs are all equivalent.
Good eye. You identified all the matching pairs.
Correct. Each of those pairs shows the same amount.

skill: Student understands that equivalence requires comparing fractions of the SAME WHOLE
problem_type: Student reads a scenario and determines whether a comparison is valid based on whether the wholes are the same size
workspace_description: Text-based scenario displayed. Multiple choice with 3-4 options requiring reasoning about whether wholes are same or different size. Optional: two same-sized FracShape bars for visual support, with dialogue establishing whether story wholes match.
prompt_examples: Emma ate 1/2 of her small cookie. Luis ate 2/4 of a large cookie. Can we say they ate the same amount?
Two identical ribbons are cut differently. One shows 1/2 shaded, one shows 2/4 shaded. Are these amounts equivalent?
Mia has a granola bar. Jake has an identical granola bar. Mia ate 3/6 and Jake ate 1/2. Did they eat the same amount?
One pizza is small, one is large. Both have 1/2 eaten. Is the amount eaten the same?
Two same-sized juice boxes. One shows 2/4 full, one shows 4/8 full. Do they have the same amount?
action_description: Student selects one answer from 3-4 multiple choice options
correct_end_state: Student has selected the answer that correctly identifies whether the comparison is valid with correct reasoning
success_dialogue: Right. The wholes are different sizes, so we can't say the amounts are equal.
Yes — identical wholes and equivalent fractions means the same amount.
Exactly. Same-sized wholes let us compare fairly.
Correct. Different-sized wholes means the comparison doesn't work.

skill: Student can explain WHY fractions are equivalent using 'same amount' reasoning
problem_type: Student views two equivalent fraction bars and selects the BEST explanation for why they are equivalent
workspace_description: Two FracShape bars displayed showing equivalent fractions. Both bars same total size with shading and labels visible. Below the bars, 4 multiple choice explanation options.
prompt_examples: Why are one half and two fourths equivalent?
These bars show three sixths and four eighths. Why are they equivalent?
What's the BEST reason these fractions are equal?
Two thirds equals four sixths. Why?
Pick the explanation that tells WHY these fractions are equivalent.
action_description: Student selects one explanation from 4 multiple choice options
correct_end_state: Student has selected the explanation that references 'same amount' or 'same portion' reasoning
success_dialogue: Exactly. They're equivalent because the same amount is shaded.
That's the key — splitting into smaller pieces doesn't change the total amount.
Right. Different pieces, but the same portion of the whole.
Yes. The shaded amount stays the same even when the pieces change.

skill: Student can select an equivalent fraction bar from a set of options
problem_type: Student selects the bar equivalent to a 1/2-family reference from 3 options
workspace_description: Reference FracShape bar at top showing a 1/2-family fraction with shading and label. Three FracShape option bars below with different partitions. One is equivalent, two are distractors. All bars same total size.
prompt_examples: Find the bar that equals one half.
Which bar is equivalent to two fourths?
Click the bar showing the same amount as three sixths.
One half is at the top. Which bar matches?
Select the equivalent bar.
action_description: Student clicks one of the three option bars to select it
correct_end_state: Student has selected the bar showing a fraction equivalent to the reference
success_dialogue: Yes. Two fourths equals one half.
That's it. Same amount, different pieces.
Correct. Three sixths and one half are equivalent.
You found it.

skill: Student can select an equivalent fraction bar from a set of options
problem_type: Student selects the equivalent bar for varied reference fractions including 2/3 family
workspace_description: Reference FracShape bar at top showing target fraction with shading and label. Three FracShape option bars below. Includes 2/3 family fractions and cross-family comparisons. All bars same total size.
prompt_examples: Find the bar equivalent to two thirds.
Which bar shows the same amount as four sixths?
Click the bar that equals three sixths.
Select the equivalent bar.
Four eighths is shown. Find its match.
action_description: Student clicks one of the three option bars to select it
correct_end_state: Student has selected the bar showing a fraction equivalent to the reference
success_dialogue: Right. Four sixths equals two thirds.
You got it. Same portion of the whole.
Correct. They're equivalent.
Yes — different pieces, same amount.

skill: Student can verify equivalence by placing fractions at the same point on a number line
problem_type: Student places a 1/2-family fraction on a number line to show it lands at the same position as an equivalent fraction
workspace_description: Two NumLines stacked vertically, both 0 to 1. Top line shows reference fraction pre-placed (e.g., 1/2 marked). Bottom line has same tick marks but no point — student places equivalent fraction. Visual comparison shows both land at same position.
prompt_examples: Place two fourths on the line. Does it land at the same spot as one half?
Show where three sixths goes. Is it the same as one half?
Put four eighths on the number line.
Place the marker at two fourths.
Find where three sixths belongs on this line.
action_description: Student drags or clicks to place a point marker on the number line
correct_end_state: Point placed at position equivalent to 1/2 (the halfway point)
success_dialogue: Right there. Two fourths lands at the same point as one half.
Yes. They're at the same position — equivalent.
Correct. Same spot means same amount.
You proved it. Three sixths equals one half.

skill: Student can verify equivalence by placing fractions at the same point on a number line
problem_type: Student places varied fractions on a number line to verify equivalence with a marked reference point
workspace_description: Two NumLines stacked vertically, both 0 to 1. Top line shows reference fraction pre-placed. Bottom line has appropriate tick marks — student places equivalent fraction. Includes 2/3 family and varied 1/2 family positions.
prompt_examples: Place four sixths on the line. Where does it land compared to two thirds?
Show where two sixths goes.
Put one third on the number line. Is it at the same spot as two sixths?
Place the marker at four eighths.
Find where two fourths belongs.
action_description: Student drags or clicks to place a point marker on the number line
correct_end_state: Point placed at correct position on number line
success_dialogue: Yes. Four sixths and two thirds are at the same position.
Correct. Same point — they're equivalent.
Right. One third equals two sixths.
You verified it. Same spot, same amount.

skill: Student can create an equivalent fraction by shading the correct number of parts
problem_type: Student shades parts of a bar to create a fraction equivalent to a 1/2-family reference
workspace_description: Reference FracShape bar at top showing 1/2-family fraction with shading and label, marked read-only. Empty FracShape bar below with different partition (e.g., eighths). Student shades parts of bottom bar to create equivalent amount.
prompt_examples: Shade this bar to show a fraction equal to one half.
The top bar shows one half. Shade the bottom bar to match that amount.
How many eighths equal one half? Shade to show.
Create a fraction equivalent to two fourths.
Shade parts to make the same amount as three sixths.
action_description: Student clicks parts of the bar to shade them
correct_end_state: Student has shaded the correct number of parts to create an equivalent fraction
success_dialogue: You made it. Four eighths equals one half.
Correct. You shaded the same amount.
Yes — same amount, just more pieces.
That's equivalent. Nice work.

skill: Student can create an equivalent fraction by shading the correct number of parts (2/3 family)
problem_type: Student shades parts of a bar to create a fraction equivalent to a 2/3-family reference
workspace_description: Reference FracShape bar at top showing 2/3 with shading and label, marked read-only. Empty FracShape bar below partitioned into sixths. Student shades parts of bottom bar to create equivalent amount.
prompt_examples: Shade this bar to show a fraction equal to two thirds.
The top bar shows two thirds. Shade the bottom bar to match that amount.
How many sixths equal two thirds? Shade to show.
Create a fraction equivalent to two thirds using sixths.
Each third splits into two sixths. Shade to show two thirds.
action_description: Student clicks parts of the bar to shade them
correct_end_state: Student has shaded the correct number of parts to create an equivalent fraction
success_dialogue: You made it. Four sixths equals two thirds.
Correct. Same amount — each third became two sixths.
Yes. Two thirds and four sixths are equivalent.
That's it. You created an equivalent fraction.

skill: Student can apply equivalence understanding to the 2/3 family
problem_type: Student identifies or verifies equivalence between fractions in the 2/3 family
workspace_description: Two or more FracShape bars showing thirds and sixths fractions. May be comparison format (two bars side by side) or selection format (reference bar with options). All bars same total size.
prompt_examples: Are two thirds and four sixths equivalent? How can you tell?
Which bar shows a fraction equivalent to two thirds?
Compare one third and two sixths. Are they equivalent?
Find the bar that equals four sixths.
Do these two bars show the same amount?
action_description: Student selects answer from multiple choice options or selects equivalent bar
correct_end_state: Student has correctly identified or verified the equivalence relationship
success_dialogue: Right. Two thirds equals four sixths.
Yes — same amount shaded in both bars.
Correct. One third and two sixths are equivalent.
You found it. They show the same portion.

skill: Student can verify equivalence for fractions greater than 1 on an extended number line
problem_type: Student places fractions greater than 1 on a 0-2 number line to verify equivalence
workspace_description: Two NumLines stacked vertically, both 0 to 2. Labels at 0, 1, and 2. Top line shows reference fraction pre-placed (e.g., 3/2). Bottom line has appropriate tick marks — student places equivalent fraction (e.g., 6/4). Visual comparison shows both land at same position beyond 1.
prompt_examples: Place three halves on the line. Where does it land?
Show where six fourths goes on this number line.
Put five fourths on the line. Is it at the same spot as another fraction?
Place the marker at three halves.
Find where six fourths belongs. What equivalent do you see?
action_description: Student drags or clicks to place a point marker on the number line
correct_end_state: Point placed at correct position beyond 1 on number line
success_dialogue: Right. Three halves and six fourths land at the same point.
Yes. They're past 1 but still equivalent.
Correct. Same position — same amount.
You proved it. Equivalence works beyond 1 too.

skill: Student can combine bar comparison and number line verification to prove equivalence
problem_type: Two-step problem: Student first selects equivalent bar, then verifies by placing both fractions on a number line
workspace_description: Step 1: Reference FracShape bar with three option bars below. Step 2: Two NumLines stacked (both 0-1) appear after correct Step 1 answer. Top line shows reference fraction pre-placed, bottom line for student placement. Validation gate between steps.
prompt_examples: Step 1: Which bar is equivalent to one half? Step 2: One half is marked on top. Place two fourths below to check.
First, find the equivalent bar. Then place it on a number line to compare positions.
Select the matching bar, then place it below the reference to verify.
Which bar equals two fourths? After you choose, place the equivalent on the bottom line.
Find the equivalent. Then show it lands at the same position as the reference.
action_description: Step 1: Student clicks to select bar. Step 2: Student places point(s) on number line.
correct_end_state: Student has selected correct equivalent bar AND placed both fractions at the same point on number line
success_dialogue: Good. You found the equivalent AND proved it on the line.
Both steps complete. Same bar, same point — equivalent.
You verified it two ways. Nice work.
Correct. Visual match and number line match.

skill: Student can apply equivalence understanding to real-world contexts
problem_type: Student determines equivalence in dialogue-framed real-world scenarios
workspace_description: Text scenario displayed with dialogue framing a real-world context. Two FracShape bars may be shown for visual support (both same size). Multiple choice with 3-4 answer options requiring reasoning about equivalence in context.
prompt_examples: Maya ate 1/2 of her chocolate bar. Noah ate 2/4 of an identical bar. Did they eat the same amount?
Two same-sized pizzas. One has 3/6 eaten, one has 1/2 eaten. Are the amounts equal?
Eli used 2/4 of his ribbon. Sara used 4/8 of an identical ribbon. Who used more?
Both sandwiches are the same size. Jade ate 1/2, Kim ate 3/6. Did they eat the same amount?
Two identical juice boxes. One is 2/4 full, one is 1/2 full. Same amount of juice?
action_description: Student selects one answer from 3-4 multiple choice options
correct_end_state: Student has correctly determined whether the amounts are equivalent based on the scenario
success_dialogue: Right. Same-sized bars and equivalent fractions — they ate the same amount.
Correct. Three sixths equals one half.
Yes. Identical ribbons and equivalent fractions means equal amounts.
You got it. Same-sized wholes, same portion eaten.

skill: Student can recognize equivalent fractions from notation without visual support
problem_type: Student selects equivalent fraction(s) from symbolic/text options without visual aids
workspace_description: No visual toys. Text/symbol display only showing fraction notation. Multiple choice with 4 fraction options displayed as text or symbols.
prompt_examples: Which fraction equals 1/2?
Select the fraction equivalent to two fourths.
Which of these is equivalent to 3/6?
Find the fraction that equals 2/3.
Which fraction shows the same amount as 4/8?
action_description: Student selects one answer from 4 multiple choice fraction options
correct_end_state: Student has selected the fraction equivalent to the target without visual support
success_dialogue: Correct. Two fourths equals one half.
Yes. Three sixths and one half are equivalent.
Right. You recognized the equivalence without needing the picture.
That's it. Four sixths equals two thirds.
